pageData.text: Students will take a provided sample of milk and through the addition of an acid, determine the pH at the <button class='glossary-text'>isoelectric point</button> of <button class='glossary-text'>casein</button>. The mass of casein will be measured and the percentage of casein in the milk sample will be calculated. As an extension, students can test their own milk sample to compare the percentage of protein.

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
pageData.text:
• Non-fat milk sample (optional)
  • Tap or bottled water

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation – 5 minutes 
Activity 1: Isolation of Casein from Dried Milk – 45 minutes + Drying Time

pageData.title: Outcomes
text: Examine the properties of proteins in general and <button class='glossary-text'>casein</button> specifically.
Explain and apply the principles of protein isolation.

pageData.text:
Proteins, when isolated from cells or tissues, can be applied in a variety of industries, such as medicine and food production. One example is insulin, the protein and hormone responsible for signaling the storage of excess glucose in the bloodstream. Our bodies produce insulin naturally, but individuals affected with type 1 diabetes produce little to no insulin and must take regular insulin injections to manage their blood sugar. The ability to provide insulin isolated from other mammals, such as pigs, allows type 1 diabetes patients to live longer, healthier lives. Another example is rennin, the enzyme found in rennet which is isolated from either plants or animals to separate curds from whey in cheese making. The process of protein isolation can be enhanced using synthetic molecules called aptamers. These synthetic aptamers are short, single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) or single-stranded RNA (ssRNA) oligonucleotide molecules that can selectively bind to a specific target. These aptamers are small and can contort themselves into a variety of shapes which makes them an extremely versatile tool for protein isolation.2014/365/307 Eight Bottles by Alan Levine is available under a CC BY 2.0 license at
https://www.flickr.com/photos/cogdog/22753934382

pageData.desc: Eight bottles of liquid insulin medication.
pageData.altText: Eight bottles of liquid insulin medication.

pageData.text: Proteins are complex organic compounds composed of monomers called <button class='glossary-text'>amino acids</button>. Amino acids contain hydrogen, oxygen, carbon, and nitrogen in three functional groups, with the general chemical formula NH<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>–RCH–COOH, where NH<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub> is an amine group and the –COOH is the carboxylic acid functional group. The –R represents a side chain, which can be an –H, a carbon chain, or a carbon ring structure. All amino acids are identical except for the –R group. All organisms require nitrogen for the construction of proteins, nucleic acids, and other compounds.

Twenty amino acids are encoded by the universal genetic code; these are known as the <button class=glossary-text>natural amino acids</button>. These 20 amino acids can be linked together by peptide bonds to form proteins. The linked amino acids can form dipeptides, tripeptides, and polypeptides. The polypeptides may contain any number, sequence, and/or configuration of amino acids to form a vast number of proteins. Proteins contained in foods are a source of <button class=glossary-text>prefabricated amino acid groups</button>. Nine amino acids are considered essential; these <button class=glossary-text>essential amino acids</button> must be supplied in prefabricated form via the diet. However, the remaining eleven amino acids can be synthesized in the human body. The absence of any of these essential amino acids halts the synthesis of crucial proteins, resulting in disease, and in prolonged cases of deprivation, death.

A common source of dietary protein is milk. is the most prevalent protein in mammalian milks: 80% of the protein in cow’s milk is casein. Casein is very poorly soluble in water, which is the base solvent of milk. The casein in milk is part of a ; an undissolved solid floating in the solvent. The protein is highly hydrophobic, meaning it is negatively attracted to water, causing the protein to form (small bubbles of protein) within the water. The exact structure of these micelles is not completely understood, but one hypothesis is that the κ-casein proteins (one type of casein protein in the micelles) are arranged such that their (charged) regions are on the surface of the micelles. Calcium and phosphate ions are present on the surface of the micelles. These ions and the polar regions of the κ-casein molecules interact with water molecules, which are also polar. The interaction of the micelles with the charged water molecules keeps the micelles suspended in the liquid phase of the milk. There are several methods of removing a suspended solid from solution. One method is to use a . A centrifuge is an apparatus that can spin a sample at a high speed and essentially force heavy materials to the bottom of a sample centrifuge tube, similar to how the spin cycle on a clothes washer helps separate the clothes from excess water. This method obviously requires expensive laboratory equipment and would not be suitable for an at-home investigation.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the chemical structure of casein in milk?

options.text: Casein is hydrophobic and forms micelles floating in the water solvent of milk.
Casein is hydrophilic and forms long strands in the water solvent of milk.
Casein is acidic and forms large clusters in the oil solvent of milk.
Casein is alkaline and forms thin, short strands in the oil solvent of milk.
Casein is electrically neutral and forms a bilayer on the surface of milk.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Casein is highly hydrophobic, causing it to form small bubbles of protein (micelles) within the water solvent of milk.

pageData.question: How do casein micelles interact with water to stay suspended in milk?

options.text: Ions and polar micelle regions attract polar water molecules.
Non-polar micelle regions repel polar water molecules.
Ions on the micelle surface repel polar water molecules.
Polar micelles regions attract non-polar water molecules.
Ions on the micelle surface attract non-polar water molecules.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The interaction of the micelles with the charged water molecules keeps the micelles suspended in the liquid phase of the milk.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Casein is the most prevalent protein in mammalian milks. Casein is very poorly soluble in water, which is the base solvent of milk. The casein in milk is part of a suspension; an undissolved solid floating in the solvent. The protein is highly hydrophobic, meaning it is negatively attracted to water, causing the protein to form micelles (small bubbles of protein) within the water. The exact structure of these micelles is not completely understood, but one hypothesis is that the κ-casein proteins (one type of casein protein in the micelles) are arranged such that their polar (charged) regions are on the surface of the micelles. Calcium and phosphate ions are present on the surface of the micelles. These ions and the polar regions of the κ-casein molecules interact with water molecules, which are also polar. The interaction of the micelles with the charged water molecules keeps the micelles suspended in the liquid phase of the milk.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Casein is the most prevalent protein in mammalian milks. Casein is very poorly soluble in water, which is the base solvent of milk. The casein in milk is part of a suspension; an undissolved solid floating in the solvent. The protein is highly hydrophobic, meaning it is negatively attracted to water, causing the protein to form micelles (small bubbles of protein) within the water. The exact structure of these micelles is not completely understood, but one hypothesis is that the κ-casein proteins (one type of casein protein in the micelles) are arranged such that their polar (charged) regions are on the surface of the micelles. Calcium and phosphate ions are present on the surface of the micelles. These ions and the polar regions of the κ-casein molecules interact with water molecules, which are also polar. The interaction of the micelles with the charged water molecules keeps the micelles suspended in the liquid phase of the milk.

pageData.text: There is another way to separate these particles, which involves changing the pH of the milk. In this investigation, acetic acid will be added to a milk sample until the , the point at which the molecule carries no net electric charge, of the protein is reached. The addition of acid changes the pH of the solution and disrupts the intermolecular forces holding the together. At the isoelectric point, the hydrogen ions (H+) from the acid balance out any negative charges on the protein, breaking up the salt bridges that give the protein their shape, and thereby reducing the strength of the intermolecular forces. This process of adding acid the protein, meaning that it is no longer in its natural molecular conformation (shape). This disruption pops the protein bubble, and the insoluble coagulates and precipitates out of solution.

Casein, while being a source of <button class='glossary-text'>essential amino acids</button>, is also the protein primarily responsible for the formation of cheese; it is the protein that coagulates to form the solid portion of cheese. In fact, the method used in this investigation is similar to ones used in the production of many cheeses. In this investigation, the percentage by weight of casein in a milk sample will be calculated.

pageData.desc: Figure 1. Diagram of casein molecules as micelles before the addition of acid and coagulated after the addition of acid.
pageData.altText: Figure 1. Diagram of casein molecules as micelles before the addition of acid and coagulated after the addition of acid.

pageData.question: One method for isolating casein from milk involves adding acid to milk. What is the role of denaturing in this process?

options.text: The change in shape disrupts the micelles, revealing insoluble casein as a precipitate.
The attraction between micelles creates molecules too large to remain suspended.
The change in polarity causes casein to become insoluble in the water solvent of milk.
The change in polarity causes casein to become soluble in water and easier to filter out.
The repulsion between micelles creates long strands that are easier to filter out.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: This process of adding acid denatures the protein, meaning that it is no longer in its natural molecular conformation (shape). This disruption pops the protein bubble, and the insoluble casein coagulates and precipitates out of solution.

pageData.question: This investigation relies on adding acid to a milk sample until it reaches its isoelectric point. How do the hydrogen ions from acetic acid affect casein’s structure at the isoelectric point?

options.text: The ions neutralize the protein’s negative charges, breaking up its intermolecular forces.
The ions increase the protein’s electrical charge, tightening its three-dimensional shape.
The ions decrease the protein’s electrical charge, adding intermolecular forces.
The ions bind to the proteins, breaking up micelles into individual proteins.
The ions bind to the proteins, allowing it to form complexes with other proteins.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: At the isoelectric point, the hydrogen ions (H<sup class=bodySupscript>+</sup>) from the acid balance out any negative charges on the protein, breaking up the salt bridges that give the protein their shape, and thereby reducing the strength of the intermolecular forces.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: In this investigation, acetic acid will be added to a milk sample until the isoelectric point, the point at which the molecule carries no net electric charge, of the protein is reached. The addition of acid changes the pH of the solution and disrupts the intermolecular forces holding the micelles together. At the isoelectric point, the hydrogen ions (H<sup class=bodySupscript>+</sup>) from the acid balance out any negative charges on the protein, breaking up the salt bridges that give the protein their shape, and thereby reducing the strength of the intermolecular forces. This process of adding acid denatures the protein, meaning that it is no longer in its natural molecular conformation (shape). This disruption pops the protein bubble, and the insoluble casein coagulates and precipitates out of solution.

pageData.desc: This map depicts the workflow for this investigation. Before starting the activity, rehydrate the dried milk. You will start activity 1 by calculating the mass of the milk sample and determining the pH of the sample. Then, add acetic acid to the sample until a precipitate forms. Next, determine the pH of the coagulated sample. Then, assemble the filtration apparatus and filter the sample through the apparatus. Then dry the collected precipitate. Lastly, calculate the mass of casein and calculate the percentage of casein in the sample.
pageData.altText: This map depicts the workflow for this investigation. Before starting the activity, rehydrate the dried milk. Next, determine the pH of the coagulated sample. Then, assemble the filtration apparatus and filter the sample through the apparatus. Then dry the collected precipitate. Lastly, calculate the mass of casein and calculate the percentage of casein in the sample.

pageData.text: Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) as described in the Safety and Procedure sections.

Acetic acid is a corrosive material. Use this chemical near a source of running water that can be used as a safety eye wash or safety shower if any corrosive material comes in contact with skin or eyes.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean up the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following should be at or near your workstation as you use acetic acid in this investigation?

options.text: a source of running water
a roll of paper towels
a fire extinguisher
an open window
a lab partner

assestmentData.question: This investigation uses a glass stir rod. Which of the following best describes the safe disposal of broken glass?

options.text: Use a broom and dustpan to collect the pieces of glass, place the glass in a secondary container, then place the secondary container in the household garbage.
Pick up the pieces of glass with gloved hands, then place the glass in the household garbage.
Use a broom and dustpan to collect the pieces of glass, then place the glass in the household garbage.
Pick up the pieces of glass with gloved hands, place the glass in a secondary container, then place the secondary container in a special receptacle on your school’s campus.
Use a broom and dustpan to collect the pieces of glass, then place the glass in a recycling bin.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following calculations will you make to describe the amount of casein isolated from a milk sample in this investigation?

options.text: percentage by weight
molar concentration
number of moles
percentage by volume
molar mass

assestmentData.question: Which of the following elements is NOT found in all amino acid molecules?

options.text: sulfur
nitrogen
oxygen
carbon
hydrogen

assestmentData.question: Casein is the most prevalent protein in mammalian milk. Which of the following terms best describes the amino acids that make up casein?

options.text: prefabricated amino acids
natural amino acids
essential amino acids
synthesized amino acids
homogenous amino acids

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the organization of casein in water, the base solvent of milk?

options.text: micelles of casein are suspended throughout the water
a bilayer of casein sits on the surface of the water
micelles of casein are dissolved in the water
an even distribution of individually dissolved casein molecules
casein solids are found at the lowest levels of the water

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the purpose of adding acetic acid to the milk sample until the isoelectric point of casein is reached?

options.text: to disrupt the intermolecular forces keeping casein in suspension
to lower the pH of the milk sample below pH 7
to transform casein from a liquid to a solid
to homogenize the suspended solids in the liquid phase of the milk
to break down casein into its amino acid monomers

assestmentData.question: Which of the following steps requires continuing the investigation overnight?

options.text: drying the casein
calculating the mass of casein
assembling the filtration apparatus
determining the pH of the milk sample
rehydrating the dried milk

You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
With the balance, weigh 10 grams of dry milk into a 250-mL beaker.
Fill beaker with tap or bottled water to the 100-mL line.
Stir using glass stir rod until thoroughly mixed.
In Activity 1, you will coagulate milk by adding acetic acid in order to filter out and isolate the milk-protein .

pages.pageTitle:
A
  Isolation of Casein from Dried Milk (18 steps)
pages.title: Isolation of Casein from Dried Milk (18 steps)

pageData.text: Weigh a small medicine cup, and record the mass in Data Table 1.
Add approximately 10 mL of rehydrated milk to the medicine cup.
Weigh the medicine cup with the milk, and record the mass in Data Table 1.
Calculate the mass of milk in the medicine cup, and record in Data Table 1.
Take the glass stir rod, and dip it into the milk sample.
Touch the milk sample to a pH indicator strip. Record color and pH in Data Table 1.
Add acetic acid drop-wise with dropping pipet while stirring with the glass stirring rod. Add drops until a precipitate ceases to form.
Dip a clean stirring rod in the clear, yellow liquid, and touch it to a pH indicator strip. Record color and pH in Data Table 1.
Weigh a piece of filter paper, and record the mass in Data Table 1.
Assemble the filtration apparatus as shown in Figure 2 with the weighed filter paper.

pageData.desc: Figure 2. Diagram and photo showing how to fold filter paper and place it into the funnel.
pageData.altText: Figure 2. Diagram and photo showing how to fold filter paper and place it into the funnel.

pageData.text: Preparing a Filtration Funnel
Place the folded filter paper into the funnel. It may be necessary to wet the funnel with water to get it to stay.
Set the funnel into the 8-oz plastic cup.
Pour the milk in the filter, and collect the solid protein in the filter paper.

Remove the filter paper containing the protein (<button class='glossary-text'>casein</button>) from the funnel, and allow to dry overnight in a cool, dry location away from pets, children, and food sources.
Weigh the dried casein and filter paper, and record the mass in Data Table 1.
Calculate the mass of casein, and record in Data Table 1.
Calculate the percentage of casein in the milk sample, and record in Data Table 1.mass of casein/mass of milk sample × 100 = percentage of casein in milk
*Optional* Repeat activity with non-fat or low-fat fresh milk sample.

pageData.title: Disposal and Cleanup
text: Dispose of solutions down the drain with the water running. Allow the faucet to run a few minutes to dilute the solutions.
Solid waste may be disposed of in the trash.
Rinse and dry the lab equipment, and return the materials to your equipment kit.

pageData.title: Questions
text: What purpose was served by filtering the milk sample after the addition of acid?
When weighing the protein at the end of the activity, what major assumption is made about the product? Why might this impact the calculated percentage of casein in the sample?
If a base, such as sodium hydroxide (NaOH) were added to milk, would the protein precipitate? Why or why not?

data.title: Amino acid
data.content: Contain hydrogen, oxygen, carbon,  and nitrogen in three functional groups, with the general chemical formula NH<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>–RCH–COOH

data.title: Casein
data.content: The most prevalent protein in mammalian milks.

data.title: Centrifuge
data.content: An apparatus that can spin a sample at a high speed and essentially force heavy materials to the bottom of a sample centrifuge tube.

data.title: Denature
data.content: It is no longer in its natural molecular conformation (shape).

data.title: Essential amino acids
data.content: Nine amino acids are considered essential and must be supplied in prefabricated form via the diet.

data.title: Isoelectric point
data.content: The hydrogen ions (H<sup class=bodySupscript>+</sup>) from an acid balance out any negative charges on the base producing a net charge of 0.

data.title: Micelle
data.content: A “bubble” that consists of a water loving (hydrophilic) core and a water phobic (hydrophobic) shell; micelles for colloidal particles.

data.title: Natural amino acids
data.content: Twenty amino acids are encoded by the  universal genetic code.

data.title: Prefabricated amino acid groups
data.content: Proteins contained in foods are a source.

data.title: Suspension
data.content: An undissolved solid floating in a solvent
